G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, because the amount in controversy, exclusive of interest and costs, does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the District Court, and because this is an action in tort.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose in Worcester County, and the Premises at issue are located at 123 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages diminished, if at all, only in proportion to any comparative negligence found, so long as his negligence, if any, was not greater than the total negligence attributable to Defendant.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: In *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), the Supreme Judicial Court abolished the prior natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and held that a property owner owes the same duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors with respect to hazards arising from snow and ice as for all other hazards.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that it is abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and that, going forward, hazards from snow and ice are governed by the same reasonable care duty as all other premises hazards toward lawful visitors. The court then applies this unified reasonable care standard retroactively, confirming that this is the operative rule of the case. The proposition accurately summarizes the holding.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.”

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of real property owes a duty to all lawful visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing on possessors of land a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants. Although the provided text is only a concurrence discussing trespassers, the majority holding squarely adopts the rule that an occupier owes lawful visitors a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe in the circumstances. Thus, the case directly supports the stated proposition for lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: "We hold that the common law distinction between licensees and invitees should be abolished and that the duty of care owed by an occupier of land should not depend upon the common law status of the injured party as a licensee or invitee. The obligation of the occupier is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk."

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Alternatively, and in addition, Defendant, as owner and person in control of the Premises, in the exercise of reasonable care should have known of the existence of the icy condition through ordinary inspection and maintenance of the Premises.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The proposition is a traditional constructive-notice argument: that the owner, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the icy condition through ordinary inspection and maintenance. Sheehan, however, expressly moves away from requiring proof that the condition existed long enough to be discovered by reasonable inspection and instead adopts the mode of operation theory, under which notice is satisfied by showing a foreseeable risk inherent in the store’s self-service operation. Thus, the case undercuts rather than supports reliance on a traditional constructive notice standard like the one stated in the proposition.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach… premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition… Of the two modern approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.… Under the mode of operation approach, a plaintiff’s proof of a particular mode-of-operation simply substitutes for the traditional elements of a prima facie case—the existence of a dangerous condition and notice of a dangerous condition.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Plaintiff did not create the hazardous condition, did not have superior knowledge of the hazard, and reasonably relied upon Defendant to maintain the sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns premises liability and the open-and-obvious danger doctrine, but it does not involve a sidewalk, nor does it analyze whether the plaintiff created the hazardous condition, had superior knowledge, or reasonably relied on the defendant to maintain a sidewalk. Instead, the hazard (trampoline next to a shallow pool) was affirmatively created and maintained by the defendants, and the opinion focuses on the landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger the landowner created and knew would be encountered. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool, with a ladder leading directly from the pool to the trampoline, for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. He knew that the pool warned against jumping of any kind, and he knew that the setup was dangerous but proceeded with the setup because he thought it would be ‘fun.’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence may be alleged, Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was less than that of Defendant and does not bar recovery under G.L. c. 231, § 85.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses G.L. c. 231, § 85 and explains that under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute a plaintiff’s contributory negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the negligence of the defendants. The court contrasts this with the absolute bar in warranty and reaffirms that, in negligence, a plaintiff whose negligence is not greater than the defendants’ remains entitled to recover, with damages proportionally diminished. This aligns with the proposition that a plaintiff’s lesser negligence does not bar recovery under § 85.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of real property owes a duty to all lawful visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including the obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition. That language matches the proposition almost verbatim. Although the case ultimately limits the duty with respect to adjacent public highways, it clearly affirms the baseline duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors on the property itself.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.proposition: Pursuant to Papadopoulos and related cases, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances, including by taking reasonable steps to inspect, treat, sand, salt, or remove accumulations of snow and ice on the Premises’ walkways and to warn of any remaining unreasonable hazards.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.support_reasoning: The case applies the then-controlling ‘natural accumulation’ rule and expressly holds that a landowner has no duty to remove or sand natural accumulations of snow and ice. While it recites the general Mounsey duty of reasonable care, it immediately narrows that duty by Aylward, concluding that there is no obligation to remove, sand, or treat naturally accumulated ice absent a change from its natural state. That is the opposite of the Papadopoulos standard described in the proposition, so this opinion does not support the cited duty rule and in fact contradicts it for the time period in question.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.relevant_excerpt: “The duty owed by a property owner to someone lawfully on the owner’s premises is one of reasonable care in the circumstances. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 (1973). In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice. Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77, 80 (1992).… [T]here can be no liability because, as was said in Aylward, supra at 79, ‘naturally accumulated snow and ice on property does not per se constitute a defective condition.’”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Defendant further had a duty, once she voluntarily undertook to shovel the sidewalk, to do so with reasonable care and not to create or leave in place an unreasonably dangerous condition worse than if she had not acted.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The provided text from Mullins v. Pine Manor College is a dissent focused on proximate cause in a campus security/rape case. It does not address negligence arising from a voluntary undertaking to perform a task (like shoveling) nor any duty to exercise reasonable care once such an undertaking has begun. There is no discussion of the ‘worse than if she had not acted’ principle related to voluntary undertakings or premises maintenance, so this case does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Defendant’s breach of her duty of reasonable care was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and the injuries he suffered to his lower back.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The case addresses duty and foreseeability and holds that Kask owed a duty of reasonable care in the storage of firearms, but it does not decide that any breach of that duty was a direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injuries. The court explicitly leaves breach and causation to the jury on remand. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that a defendant’s breach of reasonable care was the direct and proximate cause of a particular plaintiff’s injuries.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

*Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u20.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all past and future damages caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and any other compensable losses recognized under Massachusetts law.
*Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Harlow v. Chin deals with sufficiency of evidence of negligence and causation, comparative negligence, collateral source reductions, charitable immunity, and related procedural issues. It does not articulate any general rule about a plaintiff’s entitlement to “full and fair compensation” for all past and future damages including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering. While the case involves a substantial damages award, it never states the broad compensation principle asserted in the proposition, so it is not proper authority for that specific rule.

*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.raw_text: *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders, Inc.*, 441 Mass. 131, 139 (2004)
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all past and future damages caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and any other compensable losses recognized under Massachusetts law.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.case_name: Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.support_reasoning: The opinion in Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders concerns allocation of comparative negligence, inclusion of settling tortfeasors in the fault calculus, and evidentiary issues about fire safety, not the scope of recoverable damages. It does not discuss what categories of damages (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, etc.) a plaintiff may recover, nor does it articulate a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to full and fair compensation for all past and future damages under Massachusetts law. Therefore it does not support the cited damages proposition.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B and/or \u00a7 6C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover prejudgment and post‑judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and/or § 6C.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Plaintiff is further entitled to his allowable costs and fees as provided by law, including those recoverable as of right in the District Court under G.L. c. 261 and the applicable Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
